result.text: Comparative environmental assessment of methanol production technologies: A cradle-to-gate life cycle analysis
1． Introduction

In the 195Os,China’s methanol industry emerged，undergoing accelerated technological upgrading and transformation to become a major producer. Methanol, known as“clean coal,”"cheap oil,”“mobile electricity,”and “liquid hydrogen,”finds extensive application across industries, from chemicals to energy[1].G.A. Olah's[2] proposition of the “Methanol economy”anticipates its heightened prominence in the coming years,potentially ushering ina new fuel era.Currently,global methanol demand has doubled in the past decade,reaching 1O7 million tons[3].With a 99.47 million-ton production capacity in 2022—an $8 . 8 4 \%$ increase from the previous year—China leads the world methanol industry in terms of new production capacity.In the same year, China's methanol production reached 8.306 million tons, marking a $6 . 2 7 \%$ yearon-year rise[4].Methanol demand is still rising,propelled by consistent domestic economic growth and quicker developments in the chemical, electronics,and automotive industries.[5].Data indicates a notable surge in methanol consumption in China,reaching 7.8o8 million tons in apparent consumption in 2021,a $5 . 9 6 \%$ increase from the previous year [6].This trend intensified in 2022,with apparent methanol consumption hitting 9O million tons,reflecting a $1 5 . 2 6 \%$ year-on-year rise[7] Methanol,a vital chemical raw material,primarily serves downstream industries like olefins and acetic acid[3].In 2o2l,methanol to olefins accounted for $5 0 . 5 9 \%$ of demand,followed by methanol fuel at $1 5 . 6 6 \%$ [8].Diverse technologies presently produce methanol from fossil fuels such as natural gas,coal,crude oil,and biomass[9]. In China,the resource distribution -“more coal, less oil,and less gas"[4,1O] has historically favored the coal-to-olefins route ( $5 8 \%$ in 2017),with coal-togas $( 1 7 \% )$ and natural gas-to-methanol $( 1 4 \% )$ following suit[11]. Methanol production,characterized by high energy intensity,often leads to environmental challenges[12].For instance,significant emissions of acidic gases (NOx, SOx, $\mathrm { C O _ { 2 } } )$ and wastewater are commonplace [13] Additionally,gas leakage from various connecting valves during production is prevalent[14]. China's growing environmental focus accentuates the significance of studying the environmental sustainability of the methanol production industry [15].

Most environmental assessments of methanol production focus on individual technologies or a few specific routes[16].However, there are very few thorough research on the most modern carbon dioxide hydrogenation to methanol technologies as well as older traditional energy-to-methanol methods.Notably,the Carbon Capture and Utilization (CcU） route's economic and environmental features have attracted a lot of interest[17]. Gonzalez-Garay et al.[18] conducted an exhaustive evaluation of methanol production from carbon dioxide and renewable hydrogen process simulation and lifecycle analysis reveal that green methanol's current cost is 1.3 to 2.6 times higher than conventional fossil-based alternatives,mainly due to hydrogen pricing. Similarly, Perez-Fortes et al.[19] assessed methanol production using hydrogen and captured carbon dioxide,indicating limited carbon emission reduction potential compared to traditional European methods. Cuéllar-Franca et al.[2O] reviewed 27 life cycle assessment (LCA) studies on carbon capture and storage (CCS) and carbon capture and utilization (CCU) technologies,highlighting CCU's heavy reliance on renewable energy and its associated environmental imbalances. They recommend that entire lifecycle analysis,electrolysis of renewable electricity for hydrogen synthesis,and carbon dioxide purification procedures be included in LCA study for pertinent insights. Thonemann[21] conducted an analysis of LCA-based $\mathrm { C O } _ { 2 }$ chemical production, finding no $\mathrm { C O } _ { 2 }$ -based technology superior in all impact categories to conventional methods.Methanol production pathways,including biomass gasification and $\mathrm { C O _ { 2 } }$ recovery from fossil fuel-fired power station flue gases,have been explored by Shamsul et al.[22],addressing bio-methanol's potential as a renewable resource,considering global demand, economic assessment,power density,and potential applications[23]. Zhen et al.[24] describe various methanol production approaches, encompassing coal, natural gas,coke-oven gas,hydrogen,and biomass. Dalena et al.[25] review prevalent feedstocks (natural gas, $\mathrm { C O } _ { 2 } ,$ coke/ biomass） and methanol production processes,including membrane reactor technology's catalytic conversion of methanol to high-grade hydrogen.Additionally, Blumberg et.Al[26] address methanol synthesis economics with different reforming technologies, evaluating process efficiency for steam reforming,autothermal reforming,and dry methane reforming,along with economic and sensitivity analyses. Gautam et al. present a comprehensive overview of thermo-chemical and biochemical routes for sustainable bio-methanol production from waste biomass. Chen Z et al.[11] conducted a “cradle to gate” life-cycle assessment of COTM (Coal Coking to Methanol),CGTM(Coal Gasification to Methanol),and NGTM(Natural Gas to Methanol),offering a comparison of three traditional technology roadmaps. However, research comparing the LCA of all methanol production routes in China remains a gap in the current body of work.

The previous study explores the effects of several methanol routes on the environment and economy.Nevertheless,a complete analysis of the sustainability's life cycle impact along these routes has not yet been carried out. Quantifying the ecological,human,and environmental impacts of CCU chemicals—especially green methanol—is essential to fully appreciating the possble repercussions of using such methods.This will help in the development of effective plans to mitigate these possible harms.
2.Methods

Per ISO guidelines (ISO,2006a,b)[27],the LCA study involves four main steps: (1) defining goals and scope,(2) conducting a life cycle inventory (LCI) analysis,(3) performing a life cycle impact assessment (LCIA),and (4) interpretation.The study's foundational element lies in clarifying objectives and scope,depicted in Fig.1, from which the other three stages evolve.Initial stages encompass establishing the study's subject,gathering and scrutinizing data to pinpoint raw material sources,consumption patterns,and emissions.The establishment of assessment indicators comes next,and the results are then interpreted. Notably,one of the most popular tools in this industry is the eFootprint software.
2.1． Goal and scope definition

The environmental effects of five popular methanol production routes-CGTM,COTM,NGTM,BOTM,and CCTM—are compared in this study.These processes include direct carbon dioxide capture,hydrogenation with renewable energy sources,and the synthesis of methanol from coal, natural gas, biomass,and other conventional and innovative ways.In Fig.2,the individual production paths are shown.The analysis uses a“cradle to gate”boundary and concentrates on the extraction of raw materials through the manufacturing of methanol, leaving out effects connected to facilities and infrastructure.Solid garbage is delivered to a nearby landfill while wastewater is processed and repurposed. In the fuel gas system,exhaust gases are either flared or recycled.Waste catalyst is not taken into account when calculating solid waste because the catalyst used in the process has a 3-5 year replacement cycle and stays constant during the production of methanol.Notably,because the post-production processes are the same for all routes,methanol application is not addressed.Figs.3 to 7 show the system boundaries for each of the five methanol production routes (CGTM, COTM,NGTM,BOTM, and CCTM).
Case 1．Scope of Coal Gasification to MeOH (CGTM).

Fig.3 illustrates the four stages of the coal gasification methanol (CGTM) production process[28] syngas generation, syngas purification, methanol synthesis,and methanol distillation.Initially,raw coal is mined,cleaned,and introduced into a gasifier utilizing Texaco's coal water slurry gasification technology.This operation necessitates additional air separation devices to provide pure oxygen.The water-shift gas reaction alters the $\mathrm { H } / \mathrm { C }$ ratio of the crude syngas $( 2 . 1 \sim 2 . 2 )$ ,resulting in a crude syngas containing hydrogen,carbon dioxide,and other components. Subsequently,the raw gas mixture undergoes purification through the Rectisol process,Eliminate $\mathrm { C O } _ { 2 } .$ $\mathrm { H } _ { 2 } S _ { : }$ ,CO,and other compounds,while sulfur is recovered via the Super-clause procedure. Furthermore,some unreached gas is recycled back to the gasifier. Ultimately,under particular circumstances,a catalytic reaction $\mathrm { { ( C u / Z n O / } }$ $\mathrm { { A l } _ { 2 } \mathrm { { O } _ { 3 } } } \mathrm { { , } }$ converts clean gas and hydrogen into crude methanol. The next stage is to refine the crude methanol by distilling it in a special unit. This produces purified methanol.
Case 2.Scope of Coal Coking to MeOH (COTM).

Fig.4 illustrates the similarities between the coal mining and handling stages of COTM and CGTM processes.The COTM process comprises three key stages:coal processing，coke production，and methanol production[29]. Once mined and washed,hard coal undergoes pyrolysis at approximately $1 1 0 0 ~ ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ in a coke oven,yielding coke and a substantial volume of crude coke oven gas. The resulting syngas includes CO, $\mathrm { H } _ { 2 }$ $\mathrm { C H } _ { 4 } ,$ and other components,while pollutants such as benzene,ammonia,and sulfur are removed from the cooled coke oven gas.This syngas is introduced into a reforming reactor,where it undergoes reforming in the presence of an oxidant, resulting in a syngas featuring an $\mathrm { H } / \mathrm { C }$ ratio of roughly 2.5.After that, the gas from the coke furnace is compressed to provide the perfect conditions for methanol synthesis.The syngas from the reformer is subjected to elevated pressure before being transferred to the methanol synthesis reactor.After the methanol is extracted from the unreacted syngas,the remaining crude syngas is fed back into the reformer. The last stage entails reprocessing the crude methanol in a distillation unit to produce refined methanol.

Image Description: The image presents a comprehensive framework for a Life Cycle Assessment (LCA) applied to methanol production processes, structured into five main stages. The process begins with "1. Goal and scope definition," which establishes the functional unit as 1 kg of methanol, defines the system boundary from cradle to gate, and specifies assumptions such as ignoring transportation cost impact (<1%) and allocating multiple products via extension, replacement, and partition. The second stage, "2. Life cycle inventory (LCI)," involves model construction and data collection, identifying inputs and outputs across the system. Key inputs include natural resources and raw materials/energy, while outputs encompass atmospheric emissions (e.g., CO2, CH4, SO2, NOX, NH3, H2O, CFC, PO4, COD, Hg), water discharge, soil discharge, and solid waste. The third stage, "3. Life cycle impact assessment (LCIA)," characterizes environmental impacts using indicators such as Global Warming Potential (GWP), Abiotic Depletion Potential (ADP), Acidification Potential (AP), Human Toxicity Potential (HTP), Ozone Depletion Potential (ODP), and Photochemical Oxidation Potential (POP). These indicators are aggregated into comprehensive indicators through weighting and normalized indices. The fourth stage, "4. Life cycle interpretation," integrates inventory data and impact assessment results to perform improvement analysis, potential analysis, and scheme comparison and analysis, culminating in quantitative inspection and evaluation information and a final conclusion. The entire process is depicted as a sequential flow from goal definition through inventory, impact assessment, and interpretation, with feedback loops for improvement and analysis.

Image Description: The image illustrates the scope of CO₂ capture to methanol (CCTM) production, as described in Case 5. The process begins with the collection of CO₂ from various sources, including industrial production, factory emissions, and electrical and thermal emissions, which are depicted as sources of carbon dioxide. This captured CO₂ is then transported to a processing facility where it undergoes chemical absorption for purification. The purified CO₂ is subsequently used in a synthesis process to produce methanol.

The synthesis of methanol from CO₂ involves several pathways, all of which require hydrogen (H₂) as a reactant. The hydrogen is generated through water electrolysis, a process powered by renewable energy sources such as solar, wind, geothermal, wave, tidal, and nuclear energy, as well as the electrical grid. The generated hydrogen is then combined with the captured CO₂ in different reaction systems to produce syngas, which is subsequently used in the methanol synthesis reactor. The pathways for this conversion include thermochemistry, photochemistry, and electrochemistry, each representing a distinct method for catalyzing the reaction between CO₂ and H₂.

After the methanol synthesis step, the crude methanol is subjected to rectification, a purification process that separates and removes impurities and water to yield refined methanol. The overall process emphasizes the integration of CO₂ capture with renewable energy-driven hydrogen production to create a sustainable methanol synthesis pathway.

Image Description: The image illustrates the system boundary and process flow for the Coal to Methanol (COTM) process, which is divided into four main stages: raw material acquisition, raw material transporting, energy conversion, and methanol production.

- **Raw material acquisition (blue box):** This stage involves coal mining and processing, where hard coal is extracted and washed. The process consumes electricity and diesel. The output is coal slurry preparation, which is fed into the next stage. A by-product, gangue methane, is released.

- **Raw material transporting (green box):** This stage covers the transportation of coal, utilizing electricity, diesel, and road infrastructure. The output is coal transportation, which proceeds to the energy conversion stage.

- **Energy conversion (yellow box):** This stage includes coal gasification, which requires electricity and air. The air is separated in an air separation unit to produce oxygen. The coal gasification process generates syngas (CO and H₂) and produces by-products such as fly ash, exhausted gas, and slag. The syngas is then processed through a water gas shift process to adjust the H₂/CO ratio, yielding shift gas. This shift gas is fed into the methanol synthetic reactor.

- **Methanol production (pink box):** This stage involves the synthesis of methanol from the shift gas in a methanol synthetic reactor, producing refined methanol. The process is powered by electricity and air. The output is methanol, which is further processed in a product production/transportation stage. By-products include waste water, spent catalysts, and emissions to air.

- **Terminal use (teal box):** The refined methanol is used for thermal and power applications, indicating its end-use.

The system boundary encompasses all processes from raw material acquisition to methanol production, including the associated energy inputs and by-products. The diagram highlights the integration of energy conversion and methanol production stages, emphasizing the flow of materials and energy through the system.

Image Description: The image presents a process flow diagram for the Coal-to-Methanol (COTM) process, delineating its system boundary and key stages from raw material acquisition to terminal use.

The process is structured into four main stages: raw material acquisition, raw material transporting, energy conversion, and product production/transportation.

1.  **Raw Material Acquisition (Blue Box):**
    *   The process begins with the acquisition of raw coal.
    *   Electricity and diesel are required inputs for the raw coal preparation stage.
    *   This stage produces gangue and methane as outputs.

2.  **Raw Material Transporting (Green Box):**
    *   Raw coal is transported, requiring electricity, diesel, and road infrastructure.
    *   This stage produces raw coal transportation.

3.  **Energy Conversion (Yellow Box):**
    *   The coal coking process is the central energy conversion stage.
    *   It requires electricity and air, with the air separation unit producing oxygen.
    *   The primary outputs from coal coking are coal tar, sulfur, ammonia, sulfate, coke, and steam.
    *   Spent catalysts are also generated as a by-product.

4.  **Product Production/Transportation (Pink Box):**
    *   The reforming process converts the reforming gas into syngas.
    *   This syngas is fed into a methanol synthetic reactor to produce refined methanol.
    *   The final product, refined methanol, is then prepared for transportation.
    *   Emissions to air are released as a by-product of this stage.

The system boundary encompasses all the processes from raw material acquisition to product production/transportation, including the energy and material inputs and outputs for each stage.

The diagram also indicates the potential terminal uses of the products: refined methanol is used for thermal and power applications, while the by-products (e.g., coal tar, coke) may be used for thermal applications or power generation.

As depicted in Fig.5,the NGTM technology roadmap comprises two primary stages: natural gas extraction and processing,and the complete methanol production process (including syngas generation through steam reforming)[3O].After mining,a sizable amount of acidic gasses are present in the collected natural gas.Chemical absorption is first used to remove acidic gasses such as SO2 and H2S.After the acid gas is desulfurized, the natural gas is steam reformated to create syngas,and the $\mathrm { H } / \mathrm { C }$ ratio is adjusted to about 3.O.After that, the syngas is compressed and added to the synthesis reactor to create methanol.Recycled syngas is put back into the syngas furnace for additional reaction if it hasn't already. Many impurities and water are retained in the resulting crude methanol,which is then eliminated in the distillation unit to produce refined methanol.
Case 4.Scope of Biomass to MeOH (BOTM).

Fig.6 illustrates the methanol synthesis process from biomass gasification,yielding biomass methanol[31].An essential component of effectively converting high-grade biomass resources is the biomass conversion system. The supply of raw materials,biomass gasification, synthesis gas pretreatment,methanol synthesis,and end product generation are the four main steps of the process.First, biomass is subjected to necessary pretreatment, which includes granulation and drying. Subsequently,biomass gasification produces feedstock gas consisting mainly of CO, $\mathrm { H } _ { 2 } ,$ $\mathrm { C O } _ { 2 } .$ and $\mathrm { C H } _ { 4 }$ .Condensation is then employed to extract the fuel gas from the reactor. This collected gas undergoes water gas reforming (WGS) to adjust the $\mathrm { C O } / \mathrm { H } _ { 2 }$ ratio,followed by the removal of acidic gases such as $\mathrm { C O } _ { 2 }$ and H2S through the acid gas stripping system (AGR).The purified syngas is compressed and added to the methanol synthesizer in the last step,where a catalyst helps to produce crude methanol. High-quality methanol products are produced by further refining this crude methanol using the crude unit.This thorough procedure emphasizes how important each step is to producing biomass methanol in an efficient and effective manner.

Image Description: The image presents a process flow diagram illustrating the system boundary for a methanol production pathway, specifically focusing on the cradle-to-gate life cycle inventory.

The process is divided into four main stages: Raw material acquisition, Raw material transporting, Energy Conversion, and Methanol production.

1.  **Raw material acquisition (Blue section):** This stage begins with the extraction of natural gas, which is then subjected to desulfurization. The primary inputs are electricity and diesel, and the primary output is sulfur.

2.  **Raw material transporting (Green section):** This stage involves the transportation of natural gas (NG), with inputs of electricity, diesel, and road infrastructure. This stage is part of the broader natural gas processing.

3.  **Energy Conversion (Yellow section):** This stage converts the processed natural gas. It includes an Air Separation Unit, which uses electricity and air to produce oxygen. The oxygen is then used in a Primary/Secondary steam reforming process, which also requires electricity and produces light gas and water. The overall inputs are electricity and air, and the outputs are light gas and water.

4.  **Methanol production (Pink section):** This is the core synthesis stage. It utilizes the syngas (CH4/CO2/CO/H2) produced from the energy conversion stage. This syngas is fed into a Methanol synthetic reactor, where it is converted into methanol. The process requires inputs of light gas, water, and spent catalysts. The primary output is methanol, which is then used for product production and transportation.

The system boundary, defined by the dashed line, encompasses all these stages. The process outputs include emission to air and the final product, methanol, which is used for terminal applications such as thermal and power applications. The diagram also indicates that the inputs for the overall process are natural gas, electricity, and diesel, while the outputs are sulfur, N2, CO2, light gas, water, and methanol.

Image Description: The image illustrates the system boundary for the biomass-to-methanol (CGTM) process, as described in the context.

The process is divided into three main stages: Raw material acquisition, Energy conversion, and Methanol production.

1.  **Raw material acquisition (Blue box):**
    *   Biomass is acquired through planting and digestion.
    *   Inputs include H₂O and CO₂.
    *   Outputs include fertilizer and raw biomass.
    *   This stage is associated with air emissions (pesticide residue) and water emissions.

2.  **Energy conversion (Green and Yellow boxes):**
    *   **Biomass transportation (Green box):** Raw biomass is transported using diesel and road infrastructure.
    *   **Syngas gasification (Yellow box):** The transported biomass undergoes gasification, which requires electricity and thermal energy. The process produces syngas and is associated with slag, CO, NOₓ, SO₂, CO₂, and PM emissions.

3.  **Methanol production (Pink box):**
    *   **Gas conditioning:** The syngas is conditioned, which includes desulfurization and steam reforming. This step requires electricity and thermal energy and is associated with solid wastes, waste gas, wastewater, and an acid removal unit.
    *   **Methanol synthesis:** The conditioned syngas is fed into a methanol synthetic reactor, which uses a catalyst. The process produces methanol.
    *   **Distillation:** The crude methanol is refined through distillation to produce a final methanol product.
    *   This stage is associated with thermal application and power application.

The entire process is contained within the system boundary, which encompasses the cradle-to-gate stages of biomass acquisition, conversion to methanol, and purification. The system boundary includes all inputs and outputs, with the final product being methanol for terminal use.
Case 5.Scope of $\mathrm { C O } _ { 2 }$ Capture to MeOH (CCTM).

The CCTM process for methanol conversion involves three main steps: hydrogen production through water electrolysis, $\mathrm { C O } _ { 2 }$ capture, and methanol synthesis[32],illustrated in Fig.7.Large-scale water electrolysis powered by clean energy produces $\mathrm { O } _ { 2 }$ and $\mathrm { H } _ { 2 }$ .The gas is processed according to the Hua-neng Beijing $\mathrm { C O } _ { 2 }$ capture demonstration unit's process flow,going through desulfurization,denitrification,and dust removal before entering the $\mathrm { C O } _ { 2 }$ capture unit as wet saturated steam.After being cleaned,the flue gas is sent up the absorption tower, where it reacts at between 50 and $6 0 ~ ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ with the MEA packing. Subsequently，the $\mathrm { C O } _ { 2 }$ -rich solution is extracted from the bottom of the absorber tower and fed into the vaporizer.The vaporizer tower contains a reboiler at its base,heating and vaporizing the $\mathrm { C O } _ { 2 }$ .This allows it to mix with the rising gas,composed of $\mathrm { C O } _ { 2 } ,$ $\mathrm { H _ { 2 } O }$ ，anda small solvent fraction. Controlled at $1 0 5 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ ,the vapor tower facilitates the release of $\mathrm { C O } _ { 2 }$ from the mixture.Following this,the $\mathrm { C O } _ { 2 }$ stream undergoes mist elimination,condensation,and reflux to eliminate water and solvent, resulting in the production of $9 9 . 5 \% { \sim } 9 9 . 7 \%$ pure $\mathrm { C O _ { 2 } }$ gas.

The cathodic electrolyte in the $\mathrm { C O _ { 2 } }$ electroreduction unit is supplied with high-purity $\mathrm { C O } _ { 2 }$ ,which is injected into an ionic liquid and water solution until saturation.[33,34]. The electrolyzer's cathode chamber receives this mixture after which $\mathrm { C O } _ { 2 }$ is reduced to methanol.These processes take place under ambient pressure and temperature.While oxygen is produced on the anode side,hydrogen is produced on the cathode side.A proton exchange membrane separates the chambers to prevent unwanted reactions.An aqueous solution comprising unreacted $\mathrm { C O } _ { 2 }$ ，ionic liquid,water,and methanol is produced during $\mathrm { C O } _ { 2 }$ electroreduction.Additional separation and purification of unreacted $\mathrm { C O } _ { 2 }$ and solvent are needed to produce a methanol product (with a methanol mass fraction $> 9 9 \%$ )that satisfies criteria.Inputs making up less than $^ { 1 \% }$ of the total are not included in the data collecting procedure for unit processes (with a total disregard not exceeding $3 \%$ of the total input). Carbon emissions from methanol transportation and usage stages are not considered.The evaluation system boundary for the cradle-to-gate study encompasses $\mathrm { C O } _ { 2 }$ feedstock acquisition, $\mathrm { C O } _ { 2 }$ conversion to methanol, and methanol purification processes.

Image Description: The image presents a schematic of a methanol production system, delineated by a system boundary, which illustrates the process flow from raw material acquisition to terminal use. The system is divided into four main stages: Raw material acquisition, Raw material transporting, Energy Conversion, and Methanol production.

In the Raw material acquisition stage, CO₂ is captured from the atmosphere via Direct Air Capture (DAC) using a process involving Methylamine (MEA) and electricity derived from solar, wind, or hydro power plants. Concurrently, water is electrolyzed to produce hydrogen (H₂) and oxygen (O₂), also powered by renewable electricity.

The Raw material transporting stage involves the transport of CO₂ and H₂. CO₂ is transported as a compressed gas, while H₂ is transported as a compressed gas.

The Energy Conversion stage features the compression of CO₂ and H₂. The compressed CO₂ and H₂ are then fed into a methanol synthetic reactor. This reactor uses steam and electricity, which are derived from the system's own operations, to synthesize methanol. The process produces syngas (a mixture of CO₂ and H₂) as an intermediate.

The Methanol production stage involves the synthesis of methanol from the syngas. The final product, methanol, is then transported to the terminal use stage.

The system's outputs include methanol, which can be used for thermal or power applications. The process also generates various by-products and emissions: flue gas and indirect emissions from raw material acquisition; exhaust steam and waste gas from energy conversion; excess water and emissions from air and solid wastes from the methanol production stage. The system boundary encompasses all these processes, indicating that the entire lifecycle from raw material input to final product use is considered.
2.2.Life cycle inventory and data sources

The material-energy values for the life cycle of each technology route were obtained from public plant data,actual projects,or scholarly literature.Where appropriate,simulated data was used to substitute difficult-to-obtain data in order to increase realism and trustworthiness. eFootprint's database was utilized to choose particular secondary energy sources that fit China's resource environment for material dataand indirect energy in order to guarantee the study's robustness.

The main inputs for the CGTM and COTM routes encompass coal, oil, water,power,and process outputs.Equations (l-3) outline the key reactions within the methanol synthesis reactor,with a molar ratio of approximately2 between $\mathrm { H } _ { 2 }$ and $\mathrm { C O } _ { 2 }$ during the reaction.

Input and output information, covering raw material consumption, energy usage,and direct emissions for the specific process,was collected for the technology paths being studied.The data list and inventory for each technology path are presented below,and Tables 1-5 provide a detailed account of the life cycle inventory.This research gathered input and output details for the specific processes analyzed within the technology pathways,which include raw material consumption, energy utilization,and direct emissions.The data list and inventory for each technology pathway are outlined below,and Tables 1-5 offer a comprehensive representation of the life cycle inventory.

1.The Chinese Cleaner Production Standard for the Coal Mining and Processing Industry has furnished insights into material and energy utilization throughout coal mining and processing for the CGTM route. Pertinent information regarding methane leakage during coal mining in China was sourced from the statistical bulletin (National Bureau of Statistics of China,2Oo8).Data pertaining to the gasification process were derived from the IGCC plant project (NETL,201O)[35] electric power optimization with the Shanghai Coking and Chemical Company asserting the inclusion of the air separation procedure within the gasification process.Larson and Ren's 2oo3 simulations provided the data for the synthesis and distillation of methanol. Indirect coal liquefaction technology was used to produce the methanol, along with related cleaner production methods.

4.The BOTM route employs fluidized bed gasification,with biomass combustion serving as the energy source.The water vapor utilized in biomass gasification is preheated by waste heat.In order to minimize the energy input into the reforming system,this heated vapor is introduced and reacts with the biomass gas.When biomass is reformatted, the molar ratio of hydrogen to carbon dioxide is close to 2.With the resultant synthesis gas, $\mathrm { C O } _ { 2 }$ extraction is followed by methanol synthesis[39].

2.3.Life cycle impact assessment methods

The study employs eFootprint software for specialized production models.The CML2001 and Eco-indicator 99[42] methodologies characterize,normalize,standardize,and weight the life cycle environmental load inventory data for each route,enabling the calculation of the corresponding environmental impact values.Please refer to Fig.8 for the methodological framework.

The five methanol processes are commonly evaluated and compared atthe mid-point (MP)and end-point (EP) levels.The MP level evaluation is problem-oriented and focuses on environmental issues,evaluating the environmental mechanisms that link pollutant emissions to harm, while ignores the effects of environmental degradation on resources, ecosystems,and humans.The EP level assessment is a damage-oriented technique that assesses the detrimental effects on ecosystems and human health.

The CML2oo1 technique was used to assess environmental impacts at the MP level,and ten typical impact categories were chosen as MP level indicators. The midpoint impact categories in this case are(1) global warming potential 1o0 years GWP;(2) abiotic depletion potential ADP;(3) eutrophication potential EP;(4) abiotic depletion potential (ADP); (5) human toxicity potential (HTP); (6) ozone depletion potential (ODP);(7) photochemical oxidation potential (PCOP); (8) freshwater aquatic ecotoxicity potential (FAETP); (9) marine aquatic ecotoxicity potential (MAETP); (1O) terrestrial ecotoxicity potential (TETP).At the EP level,impacts on ecosystems and human health were evaluated using eight ecological indicators,as given in Table 6,utilizing the Ecoindicator The main gases causing global warming are $\mathrm { C O } _ { 2 }$ $\mathrm { C H } _ { 4 }$ and $\mathrm { N O } _ { 2 }$ with $\mathrm { C O } _ { 2 }$ being the reference gas.

The acidification effect stems from pollutants like $s 0 _ { 2 }$ $\mathrm { N O } _ { \mathrm { X } } ,$ and $\mathrm { N H } _ { 3 }$ ,with acidification potential quantified in equivalent kg of $S O _ { 2 }$ .This measure illustrates the ability of released contaminants to produce and release hydrogen ions. On the other side,eutrophication results from the entry of N,P,and other elements into water bodies.This causes an excessive growth of aquatic plants,a drop in oxygen levels,and a deterioration of the water quality.Non-material depletion pertains to resources and energy consumed in product production. Ozone Depletion Potential (ODP) primarily results from human-generated HCFC compounds and trace gases that harm the ozone layer,notably Freon. Solvents and other volatile organic chemicals are involved in processes that are catalyzed by sunlight to create photochemical ozone.

Image Description: The image presents a methodological framework for life cycle assessment (LCA) of methanol production processes, integrating the CML2001 and Eco-indicator 99 methodologies.

- The framework is structured into two primary phases: the LCA Mid-Point (MP) and the LCA End-Point (EP).
- The CML2001 Method, applied at the MP level, evaluates ten midpoint impact categories: Global Warming Potential (GWP), Abiotic Depletion Potential (ADP), Acidification Potential (AP), Freshwater Aquatic Ecotoxicity Potential (FAETP), Marine Aquatic Ecotoxicity Potential (MAETP), Terrestrial Ecotoxicity Potential (TETP), Human Toxicity Potential (HTP), Eutrophication Potential (EP), Ozone Depletion Potential (ODP), and Photochemical Oxidation Potential (PCOP).
- Each of these ten midpoint impact categories is quantified using specific equivalence units, such as kg CO2-Equiv for GWP, kg DCB-Equiv for ecotoxicity, kg Phos-Equiv for eutrophication, kg R11-Equiv for ODP, and kg Ethene-Equiv for PCOP.
- The midpoint impact results are then aggregated and mapped to the end-point level using the Eco-indicator 99 Method.
- The Eco-indicator 99 Method categorizes the integrated impacts into three main damage domains: Resource, Ecosystem, and Human Health.
- The Ecosystem domain is further divided into sub-categories of Land conversion (LC), Acidification/Eutrophication (AC/EC), and Ecotoxicity (EC).
- The Human Health domain includes Climate Change (CC), Radiation (RA), Cancer (CE), and Inorganic (IR) and Organic (OR) pollutants.
- The integration process is indicated by the flow of arrows from the CML2001 midpoint categories to the Eco-indicator 99 damage domains, culminating in the calculation of an overall "Integrated Impact".
- The diagram visually represents the transition from a problem-oriented, mechanistic evaluation (MP) to a damage-oriented assessment (EP) that evaluates impacts on ecosystems and human health.

Human health damage is gauged using disability adjusted life years (DALY), encompassing years of life lost and impaired. Ecosystem quality harm is expressed as the potentially disappeared fraction (PDF),representing the percentage of species that might vanish due to environmental influences,signifying ecosystem degradation.Inventory analysis computes environmental pressure for each process unit, followed by comprehensive analysis to evaluate potential environmental impacts.

Sensitivity analysis refers to the degree of impact that changes in the consumption of a material or energy have on changes in results[43]. Expressed mathematically,itis the ratio of the change in material or energy consumption to the change in result.The larger the ratio,the greater the impact of changes in the material or energy consumption on the results,that is,the more sensitive it is.This formula is depicted in equation (10).

Z represents sensitivity, $y _ { i }$ is the amount of energy originally input, $y _ { o }$ is the amount of energy remaining after consumption, $y _ { i } – y _ { o }$ is the change in energy consumption.

To gauge the sensitivity of material and energy parameters to specific environmental impacts,this study employs a sensitivity analysis approach involvinga ${ \bf 1 0 \% }$ adjustment to input data.Parameters exhibiting lower sensitivities,below $0 . 0 2 \%$ ,are considered negligible in this study and are excluded from consideration.
3．Results and discussion

The five common methanol pathways share similar ingredient profiles,utilizing 13 distinct input materials from the environment, encompassing both non-renewable and renewable resources.Emissions are categorized into inventory,air,water,and soil emissions.These emissions comprise heavy metals,inorganic and organic chemicals,with topsoil,waste,and degraded goods as the primary stockpiles.Notably, heavy metals and inorganic compounds dominate pollutants released into the air,water,and agricultural and industrial soils.

As a leading producer and consumer, China's methanol industry is expected to grow alongside emerging downstream industries.However, environmental concerns arise due to its heavy reliance on fossil fuels for production.This study employs the eFootprint software to comprehensively assess the environmental impact of various methanol production pathways - coal to methanol (CGTM),coke oven gas to methanol (COTM),natural gas to methanol (NGTM),biomass to methanol (BOTM),and carbon dioxide hydrogenation to methanol (CCTM). Through a life cycle evaluation,this research examines the environmental footprint of these pathways.
3.1.Life cycle assessment results and environmental performanct

Fig.9 illustrates the material and energy flows for each of the five pathways.The data for the methanol production routes were organized based on input and output analyses within the life cycle software to gain clarity on pollutant emissions. Coal mining requires $1 . 2 5 ~ \mathrm { k g }$ of diesel, $1 2 . 5 \mathrm { k W h }$ of electricity,and $_ { 0 . 7 \mathrm { ~ t ~ } }$ of water to yield1 t of coal.

In Fig.9(a),coal gasification employs 1.23 t of syngas,1.533 t of hard coal, $\mathbf { 1 . 5 3 k g }$ of crude oil, $1 4 . 2 \mathrm { k g }$ of water,and 825 kWh of electricity to produce 1 t of methanol. The process yields 1.23 t of crude gas using $_ { 1 . 3 8 \mathrm { ~ t ~ } }$ of hard coal, $\mathbf { 1 . 7 7 ~ t }$ of high-pressure steam, $4 3 4 8 . 2 \ \mathrm { k g }$ of air, $4 3 4 8 . 2 \mathrm { k g }$ of water,and 11o8.30 kWh of electricity.Additionally, this operation generates $1 5 3 \mathrm { k g }$ of coal gangue and $7 . 6 4 \mathrm { k g }$ of methane gas. Similarly,producing 1 t of methanol from coal coking necessitates $1 9 6 8 . 6 6 \mathrm { N m } ^ { 3 }$ of coke oven gas,678.32 kWh of energy,2.25 tof mediumpressure steam, $^ { 1 . 1 4 \mathrm { t } }$ of deionized water,and 6.19 tof clean water.This process also generates $1 3 2 4 \mathrm { k g }$ of washed coal, $2 1 5 . 8 \mathrm { k g }$ of heat, $1 6 3 \mathrm { k g }$ of compressed air, $1 0 ~ \mathrm { k g }$ of $9 8 \%$ sulfuric acid, $0 . 0 0 3 ~ \mathrm { k g }$ of sodium hydroxide, and $1 6 3 \mathrm { M J }$ of power per 1 t of coke oven gas.

According to Fig. 9b, $6 1 7 \mathrm { N m } ^ { 3 }$ of natural gas, $5 7 6 . 4 \mathrm { k W h }$ of energy, $1 4 2 \mathrm { N m } ^ { 3 }$ of oxygen,1.14 tof pure water,3.6 tof distilled water, $0 . 2 \mathrm { k g }$ of sodium hydroxide,and $0 . 1 5 ~ \mathrm { k g }$ of sodium phosphate are all needed to produce 1 tof methanol from natural gas.Moreover, in order to generate 617 $\mathrm { N m } ^ { 3 }$ of natural gas, $4 7 . 3 9 ~ \mathrm { k g }$ of hard coal, $1 1 . 9 7 ~ \mathrm { k g }$ of crude oil, $0 . 0 5 ~ \mathrm { \ k g }$ of iron,and $2 0 . 1 1 \ \mathrm { \ k g }$ of fuel gas are needed,while the byproducts emitted are 153,5.44,0.48,0.39,0.043,and $0 . 0 2 5 ~ \mathrm { k g }$ of $\mathrm { C O } _ { 2 }$ $\mathrm { C H } _ { 4 }$ $\mathrm { N O } _ { \mathrm { X } } ,$ $s 0 _ { \mathrm { X } } ,$ CO,and PM, respectively.

According to Fig. 9(c). Biomass gasification requires $1 3 6 . 1 1 ~ \mathrm { k g }$ of hydrogen and $8 7 4 . 9 5 ~ \mathrm { k g }$ of carbon monoxide gas to produce $^ \mathrm { ~ 1 ~ t ~ }$ of methanol, in addition to 217.4 kWh of electricity,and consumes $1 0 . 8 \mathrm { k g }$ of water and $_ { 0 . 8 \mathrm { ~ t ~ } }$ of steam.Because of photosynthesis,biomass feedstock is a renewable energy source that reduces atmospheric $\mathrm { C O } _ { 2 }$ during the course of its growth.As a result, neither the $\mathrm { C O _ { 2 } }$ released during the production process nor the overall amount of $\mathrm { C O } _ { 2 }$ fixed in methanol causes a rise in the atmospheric $\mathrm { C O } _ { 2 }$ concentration.

The flow of the process for producing methanol from biomass straw is shown in Fig. 9(c). The supply of feedstock,biomass gasification, syngas pretreatment, methanol synthesis,and final product output are the four primary components of the biomass methanol process flow.The process for producing methanol is biomass gasification synthesis. Initially,biomass is prepared through drying and pelletization, followed bygasification in the biomass gasifier to yield raw gas predominantly composed of cO, $\mathrm { H } _ { 2 } .$ $\mathrm { C O } _ { 2 } ,$ and $\mathrm { C H } _ { 4 }$ .Subsequently, processes such as desulfurization,decarbonization,adjustment of the $\mathrm { H } _ { 2 }$ to CO volume ratio,and $\mathrm { C H } _ { 4 }$ reforming are employed to transform the raw gas into syngas meeting the prerequisites for methanol synthesis.After that, a methanol synthesis column is fed the syngas to produce crude methanol. Ultimately,distilling the crude methanol yields high-quality methanol.

Fig.9(d) outlines the methanol synthesis process through direct air carbon capture $^ +$ hydrogen.To produce 1 t of methanol using direct carbon capture, you require $2 2 0 . 6 \mathrm { k g }$ of hydrogen, $1 6 1 7 . 4 \mathrm { k g }$ of carbon dioxide gas,217.4 kWh of power,and $1 0 . 8 ~ \mathrm { k g }$ of water. The carbon dioxide is derived from directair carbon capture.This method involves passing air through a chemical solution,like sodium carbonate and potassium hydroxide,to extract $\mathrm { C O _ { 2 } }$ from the environment. The chemical recovery is then finished at high temperatures,and the leftover air is discharged back into the atmosphere.Furthermore,this approach employs localized utilization of $\mathrm { C O } _ { 2 }$ ,eliminating the need for extensive transportation.

For capturing 1 t of $\mathrm { C O } _ { 2 }$ ,0.91 tons of air,341.61 tons of oxygen, 1148.03 tons of nitrogen,18.43 tons of water, 0.12 tons of natural gas, 2342.31 tons of sodium carbonate,and O.12 tons of potassium hydroxide solution are necessary. In the calcination process, 0.34 tons of oxygen and O.02 tons of nitrogen are utilized. During this capture procedure,water, $\mathrm { C O } _ { 2 } ,$ and nitrogen are released.

Image Description: The image illustrates the process flow for the Natural Gas to Methanol (NGTM) route, a pathway for methanol production. The process begins with the extraction and processing of natural gas, which involves the use of 617 Nm³ of natural gas and 47.39 kg of hard coal. This is followed by the reforming section, where 576 kWh of electricity is consumed to convert the natural gas into synthesis gas. The synthesis gas then undergoes CO₂ absorption using KOH and K₂CO₃ as adsorbents. Concurrently, desulfurization of natural gas requires 3.6 tons of desalinated water. The synthesis gas is then transported to the methanol production unit, where it is converted into methanol. The overall process is powered by electricity sourced from a mix of energy sources, including coal, hydropower, wind, solar, and nuclear, with coal being the dominant source at 66.5%. The NGTM route exhibits the lowest impact in several categories such as eutrophication potential (EP), human toxicity potential (HTP), ozone depletion potential (ODP), photochemical oxidation potential (POCP), and marine aquatic ecotoxicity potential (MATEP), indicating reduced industrial waste discharge. However, it contributes significantly to the abiotic depletion potential (ADP) and has notable values in global warming potential (GWP), acidification potential (AP), and terrestrial ecotoxicity potential (TETP), primarily due to natural gas leakage during mining and processing.
3.1.1．The Middle-point level analysis

The CML2oo1 approach[44] was employed to assess the environmental impacts of LCA for CGTM,COTM,NGTM,BOTM,and CCTM across ten categories.For the baseline scenario evaluation, the average power of the Chinese grid in 2022 was adopted from the eFootprint program.This baseline electricity profile was applied to all input materials for the common methanol production routes: CGTM,COTM, NGTM,and BOTM. The distribution of typical electricity sources is as follows: $6 6 . 5 \%$ coal, $1 5 . 3 \%$ hydropower, $8 . 6 \%$ wind, $4 . 8 \%$ solar power, $4 . 7 \%$ nuclear power.

In the case of the unique hydrogen source characteristic of the new CCTM route,electricity for hydrogen electrolysis is sourced from renewable energy.The average electricity consumption for other aspects of CCTM remains consistent across the board.
1) Comparative total impact analysis

Fig.1O illustrates the impact categories among the five methanol production routes.The highest MAETP value results from emissions like ammonia nitrogen,oil substances,phosphate,sulfides,and heavy metals during methanol production.AP (acidification potential),EP (eutrophication potential),POCP (photochemical oxidation potential),FATEP (freshwater aquatic ecotoxicity potential),and TETP(terrestrial ecotoxicity potential) values have similar magnitudes,around 1O orders of magnitude,indicating comparable acidic and organic gas emissions and their impacts on freshwater resources and terrestrial ecotoxicity.In contrast, ODP (ozone depletion potential) holds the lowest value, indicating minimal ozone layer depletion.

Image Description: The image presents a comparative analysis of five methanol production routes—CGTM, CGTM, NGTM, BOTM, and CCTM—across ten environmental impact categories: GWP, AP, EP, HTP, ODP, POCP, FATEP, MATEP, TETP, and ADP.

The CGTM route exhibits the highest fossil energy consumption, with the coal treatment stage contributing 65.2%, syngas production 19.85%, and methanol synthesis 15.85% to the total ADP. The syngas production stage is a major contributor to AP, FATEP, MATEP, and TETP impacts, with over 50% of its contribution in these categories stemming from the release of radioactive elements like Kr during electricity and steam production. This stage also accounts for over 40% of GWP, EP, and HTP impacts and over 90% of ODP. Approximately 40% of the impacts in these categories are linked to methanol production. The positive correlation between AP and GWP is attributed to the release of CO₂ from fossil fuel combustion.

The NGTM route displays the lowest impact in EP, HTP, ODP, POCP, and MATEP categories, indicating lower industrial waste discharge. It contributes the most to the ADP category and has significant values in GWP, AP, EP, POCP, FATEP, MATEP, and TETP. These outcomes are largely due to environmental effects from natural gas leakage during mining and processing. Despite its notable MATEP influence, NGTM remains the smallest among the five routes at 1.05E+05 kg DCB-Equiv, which is half that of coal gasification to methanol and one-third of coke oven gas to methanol, similar to BOTM and CCTM. The impact of EP, HTP, POCP, and MATEP categories is minimal across all routes, underscoring reduced nitrogen, phosphorus, and volatile organic compound emissions during the natural gas to methanol stages.

The BOTM process has a negative total GWP value, indicating reduced greenhouse gas emissions compared to consumption. Its AP, EP, POCP, FATEP, MATEP, and TETP values align closely with NGTM, implying similar acidic and organic gas emissions and ecotoxicological impacts. BOTM's POCP is the lowest among all routes at 3.32E-10 kg R11-Equiv, demonstrating minimal acidification or eutrophication impact on land environments. Its AP value is 3.206 kg SO₂-Equiv, and EP is 0.3308 kg Phos-Equiv. BOTM records the lowest ADP among the five paths, utilizing the fewest resources overall, primarily due to fossil energy consumption. Biotoxicity HTP primarily stems from pesticides in rice straw growth and CO, SO₂, and NOx emissions during methanol production. The terrestrial ecotoxicity TETP value, akin to AP and FATEP, ranks lowest among the five routes.

The CCTM route demonstrates the highest biotoxicity HTP and POCP among all routes but experiences the least variance in ecotoxicity across environments (FATEP, MATEP, TETP). Consequently, CCTM is relatively less clean, with higher EP, ADP, ODP, POCP, FATEP, and TETP values than coke oven gas-derived methanol, indicating elevated environmental pollution levels.

- The NGTM route exhibits a high contribution from natural gas processing to the ADP category, while methanol production contributes significantly to GWP, AP, EP, POCP, FATEP, MATEP, and TETP. The minimal impact in EP, HTP, POCP, and MATEP across all routes indicates low emissions of nitrogen, phosphorus, and volatile organic compounds during the natural gas to methanol stages.
- The BOTM route shows that biomass processing is the dominant contributor to most impact categories, with biomass gasification and methanol production also contributing significantly. The AP value of 3.206 kg SO₂-Equiv and EP value of 0.3308 kg Phos-Equiv are noted, and the POCP value of 3.32 E-10 kg R11-Equiv is the lowest among all routes. BOTM records the lowest ADP and ranks lowest in TETP, AP, and FATEP.
- The CCTM route is characterized by a high contribution from CO₂ capture to the GWP impact category. The water electrolysis stage is the primary contributor to HTP, and methanol production contributes significantly to ADP, POCP, FATEP, MATEP, and TETP. CCTM demonstrates the highest biotoxicity HTP and POCP among all routes, indicating higher environmental pollution levels compared to other pathways.
environmental pollution levels.
2) Comparative process impact analysis

Fig.11 displays the fractional share of each technology unit in the overall technology process and the share of each technology unit in the 10 categories of impacts for each of the five technological pathways for methanol.

The CGTM technology route's coal treatment stage $( 6 5 . 2 \% )$ , syngas production stage $( 1 9 . 8 5 \% )$ ,and methanol synthesis stage $( 1 5 . 8 5 \% )$ have the greatest fossil energy consumption ADP.More than $5 0 \%$ of the syngas production stage's contribution to the AP,FATEP,MATEP,and TETP impacts comes from the release of radioactive elements like Kr during the production of electricity and steam. This contribution is above $4 0 \%$ for GWP,EP,and HTP,and over $9 0 \%$ for ODP.Additionally, about $4 0 \%$ of these impact categories are related to the production of methanol.The AP contribution's positive correlation with the GWP can also be explained by the fact that the carbon fixed in fossil fuels gets released into the atmosphere as $\mathrm { C O } _ { 2 }$ ，which causes the greenhouse effect.Itis necessary to recover $\mathrm { C O } _ { 2 }$ from exhaust fumes in order to reduce the greenhouse effect of methanol manufacture.

The entire stage of the COTM technology pathway is an energyintensive process, however the effects of the methanol synthesis stage account for a disproportionate amount $( > 7 5 \% )$ of the total energy use. Similar to the CGTM route, $8 0 . 1 \%$ of the effects of ADP come from the stage of coal mining and treatment. Second,the impacts of GWP and POCP in the coal handling stage are rather significant,accounting for $2 0 . 3 \%$ and $1 8 . 9 5 \%$ ，respectively.This is mostly because the coal handling stage releases a lot of $\mathrm { C O } _ { 2 }$ and NOX.Additionally, EP and ODP have the biggest effects during the coke production stage.This is largely because this step uses a lot of steam and electricity while producing N,P, and other radioactive elements.

The natural gas extraction and processing stages in the NGTM technology route have significant environmental effects $( 2 5 \% )$ .In addition to its largest contribution in the ADP category,the GWP,AP, EP,and POCP categories also have relatively large shares,which are primarily due to environmental impacts caused by natural gas leakage during the extraction and processing stages,such as acidic gases, methane，and hydrocarbon gases.Given that MAETP and TETP accounted for nearly all of the electricity used during the stages of methanol production and gas mixture reforming,which had significant negative effects on the environment $( 7 0 - 9 9 \% )$ ,it can be said that the methanol production stage has the most impact on terrestrial and marine ecosystems.

The BOTM technology route results in negative GHG emissons as atmospheric $\mathrm { C O } _ { 2 }$ is transformed to methanol, which perfectly captures the benefits of biomass in the carbon cycle.However,the gasification process stage has the highest emissions of $\mathrm { N O } _ { \mathrm { X } } ,$ $S O _ { 2 } ,$ ,and total suspended particulate matter (TSP) in this stage,according to the ODP,which is more specific among all impact categories and reaches up to $5 5 . 2 1 \%$ This is primarily because so much renewable energy is used in this stage. The GWP AP EP ADP POCP FAETP percentage for the methanol manufacturing stage ranges from $6 5 \%$ to $8 5 \%$ ,indicating that it significantly pollutes freshwater resources and the atmosphere.Overall, though,the BOTM method is far superior at reducing the effects of global warming.

Because the eFootprint process employs steam and electricity,the CO2 capture stage of the CCTM technology approach contributes to approximately $7 0 \%$ of the overall environmental effects.ODP is the most concentrated effect category,contributing $8 0 . 1 5 \%$ of the total impact; the stage of hydrogen synthesis accounts for the majority of its contribution.This is due to the fact that producing hydrogen necessitates a large amount of renewable energy,such as producing resins for windmill construction and polysilicon panels for renewable energy construction,both of which release compounds that deplete the ozone layer.
3) Comparative sub-process impact analysis

This research analyze the environmental impacts of each of the five stages in methanol production, focusing on raw material preparation, transportation,auxiliary engineering steps (such as air separation and high-pressure steam),public engineering steps (including heat supply systems,demineralization stations,and circulating water systems),and the methanol production process.The proportional figures in Fig.1O are represented in Fig.12 for each subprocess.Of them,raw material preparation, the second-most important sub-process,has an environmental impact that ranges from $9 . 3 5 \%$ to $3 8 . 0 2 \%$ ，which is similar to that of the methanol manufacturing process. Conversely,the process's least environmentally damaging element, transportation, has an impact that ranges from $4 . 9 2 \%$ to $1 9 . 8 9 \%$ .Auxiliary engineering operations have an intermediate environmental impact, ranging from $7 . 6 0 \%$ to $2 7 . 1 5 \%$ .The methanol production phase dominates these ten impact categories, ranging from $- 2 5 . 0 9 \%$ to $3 9 . 9 7 \%$ ,thereby constituting the most significant component of the subprocesses.The environmental impacts of public engineering processes vary from $8 . 8 9 \%$ to $3 3 . 0 1 \%$

In CGTM, the feedstock preparation impact value on ADP is 23,916 MJ,comprising $3 7 \%$ of the entire production process,consistent with the findings in Fig.11.Moreover,methanol production accounts for $3 0 . 3 5 \%$ of the process's impact on ODP,making it the most influential process.The 1O impact categories show that the environmental impact of methanol manufacturing ranges widely, from $1 6 . 1 9 \%$ to $3 0 . 3 7 \%$ .The processes that prepare raw materials,transportation,auxiliary engineering,public works,and methanol production have a greater overall impact on HTP than this one,with respective proportions of $2 6 . 9 1 \%$ $1 6 . 4 4 \%$ ， $1 4 . 9 5 \%$ ， $1 6 . 4 4 \%$ ，and $2 5 . 2 6 \%$ .The distribution of the remaining seven impact categories,which include auxiliary engineering,public works,transportation,raw material processing,and methanol production,is very uniform,with the exception of ADP.

In COTM, the methanol production stage accounts for over $8 0 \%$ of the environmental load, primarily due to electricity and medium pressure steam usage. This technology has minimal impact on ODP and POCP.However, it significantly influences ADP and MATEP,with figures ranging from $2 2 . 9 5 \%$ $8 . 1 9 \%$ $1 8 . 4 4 \%$ $2 2 . 5 4 \%$ ,and $2 7 . 8 6 \%$ for raw material preparation，transportation，auxiliary engineering，public works,and methanol production,and $2 6 . 0 8 \%$ ， $1 2 . 5 0 \%$ ， $1 9 . 5 6 \%$ $1 9 . 5 6 \%$ for MATEP.Except for ODP and POCP,which are 0.38 to 0.52 times higher than the effect categories of CGTM, COTM's impact on ADP is comparable to CGTM's impact on ADP.Notably, the coke oven gas method offers substantial environmental and financial advantages over CGTM.

In NGTM, the influence of PWP and methanol production on TETP, MATEP,and FATEP is approximately1:1,underscoring the need for a compatible heat supply,recycling system,and more for biomass production in tandem with methanol production.Among all effect categories,the most substantial impacts were observed in EP due to raw material preparation $( 3 8 . 0 2 \% )$ and methanol manufacturing $( 3 1 . 5 6 \% )$ Furthermore,with a value of $1 . 2 ~ \mathrm { k g }$ DCB-Equiv and a percentage of $2 7 . 1 5 \%$ ,the auxiliary engineering process exhibits the most pronounced impact on TETP,emphasizing that synthesizing methanol from natural gas involves high-pressure steam and considerable energy consumption for air separation.

In BOTM,methanol production's TETP and MATEP values were $^ { 3 9 , 1 5 6 ~ \mathrm { k g } }$ DCB-Equiv and $1 . 1 2 \ \mathrm { k g }$ DCB-Equiv,respectively, signifying the severe terrestrial and marine ecotoxicity arising from the intensive pesticide use,impacting non-target organisms in terrestrial ecosystems. The cultivation technique of biomass played a role in the EP effect. Moreover,gasification and reforming significantly contributed to HTP, particularly within the methanol production and raw material preparation stages,with potentials of $5 6 0 ~ \mathrm { k g }$ DCB-Equiv and $4 6 9 ~ \mathrm { k g }$ DCBEquiv,respectively,accounting for $4 1 . 8 5 \%$ and $3 5 . 0 5 \%$

Among the five technology pathways,CCTM stands out with the greatest impacts on HTP and POCP.In HTP,the methanol production process claims the largest share,accounting for $2 8 . 8 3 \%$ ，while the transportation process holds the smallest share at $8 . 5 4 \%$ .Conversely, CCTM's impact on AP is the lowest among the five technical pathways.

3.1.2. The End-point level analysis

The Eco-indicator 99 (Endpoint) model was used to assess the environmental consequences of five methanol manufacturing processes, which were assessed and studied at the ecosystem and human health levels,respectively,with the ecosystem impacts including three impact factors,LU EC AC/NC.Five impact factors on human health are OR IR RA CC CE.Similarly,to the midway study,the environmental implications of the endpoint model were examined in general as well as for each technology unit and sub-process. Comparative total impact analysis.
1) Comparative total impact analysis

Both CGTM and COTM manufacture methanol from coal, which results in the discharge of a considerable number of hazardous gases and compounds such as $\mathrm { C O } _ { 2 }$ $S O _ { 2 } ,$ and $\mathrm { N O } _ { \mathrm { X } } ,$ which destroy the ecology.In comparison to CGTM and COTM,NGTM has a reduced environmental impact. Natural gas resources are typically found in more remote places, therefore mining has a lower environmental impact.Furthermore, because natural gas is cleaner than coal,the process of producing methanol has a low impact on acidification and eutrophication of the land.NGTMuse renewable biomass asa fuel in a sequence of chemical reactions to produce methanol.NGTM has a lower impact on land resources than the usage of fossil fuels.Crop residues,wood wastes,and industrial organic wastes,among other things,are recycled during the biomass production process.This decreases trash pollution on the ground and enhances land resource usage.Furthermore, the carbon dioxide created by BOTMcan be absorbed byplants,forminga biological cycle that does not significantly acidify or eutrophicate the land environment. The environmental impact of CCTM is mostly determined by the energy source and carbon dioxide emissions employed in the manufacturing process.Using clean energy as the energy input and beingable to absorb and store carbon dioxide efficiently,the environmental impact of renewable energy equipment is primarily focused on in the manufacturing process of photovoltaic panels.

Fig.13's research indicates that all approaches have a greater endpoint effect category impact on ecosystems,suggesting that these methanol manufacturing processes may harm land and water. Damage to ecosystem quality and human health caused by CGTM is $3 3 4 \mathrm { P D F } / \mathrm { m } ^ { 2 }$ a and 0.0159 DALYs,which are 2.1,3.6,3.5,and 1.6 times higher than those caused by COTM,NGTM,BOTM,and CCTM,respectively.This research has shown that that CGTM causes the most ecological harm to water resources,land resources,and so on,while CCTM causes damage similar to CGTM,and the value of CCTM's influence on the ecosystem is higher than that of COTM,NGTM,and BOTM.Among the human health consequences,the overall value of harm to human health (Human Health)of CGTMis 2.15 times that of COTM,whereas the damage values of NGTM and BOTM are lower,0.00144 DALY and 0.00454 DALY, respectively. Overall, the effects of each technological option on ecosystems outweigh their effects on human health,suggesting that the potential for modifying ozone layer depletion,eutrophication,and global warming is greater for ecosystems than for humans.

As observed in Fig.16,the coal gasification process's acidification and eutrophication damage values are increased due to the syngas generation process of the CGTM process's high emissions of carbon and nitrogen oxides.Both the ecosystem and human health have suffered severe harm.Particularly,the COTM's methanol synthesis phase causes more harm to the environment and to people's health.Compared to previous steps in the COGM,NGTM,and BOTM pathways, the methanol synthesis stage is more harmful to the environment. 3) Comparative sub-process impact analysis

Fig.18 displays the percentage of the five pathways'effects on AC/ NC,EC,and LU at each stage.Similar to how the MP level was analyzed, the effects of the five methanol production routes were examined with regard to rawmaterial preparation,transportation,auxiliary engineering processes (air separation unit),public engineering processes (heatingsystem，distillate system，and recycled water system)，and environmental impacts.The demand for raw materials and accessories as well as the overall methanol production process’recycle rate impact the outcomes of the auxiliary engineering processes (see Fig.19).

In AC/NC,CCTM contributes $7 0 \%$ of CGTM during the feedstock preparation stage,and the other three technologies contribute $2 0 \%$ to $2 8 \%$ . In the transportation stage,COTM,NGTM, BOTM,and CCTM each make up ${ } ^ { 2 3 \% }$ to $3 0 \%$ of CGTM, while COTM makes up $4 5 \%$ of CGTM in the auxiliary engineering process stage.The other three processes each make up a smaller portion of AC/NC,ranging from $1 5 \%$ to $2 0 \%$ .With contribution ratios of more than $4 0 \%$ for the public works processes, each process is more dependent on it,resulting in a bigger environmental impact. 3.2.Sensitivity analysis

Using ADP,AP,HTP,and GWP as representative categories,sensitivity analysis was used to identify the key variables influencing the evaluation outcomes.To determine the level of influence,input data for the material and energy parameters were modified by $1 0 \%$ .The use of electricity for coal mining and processing in the CGTM and COTM routes,for example,was disregarded because its sensitivity was less than $0 . 0 2 \%$ .ADP,AP,HTP,and GWP were selected as representative categories (each endpoint categorization having similar sensitivity to midpoint influences).

The most sensitive parameter is the amount of power used to produce syngas,as seen in the sensitivities for the CGTM route in Fig.2O.For the AP HTP GWP impact category,the overall sensitivity of electricity will be $6 . 3 1 \%$ $6 . 7 3 \%$ ,and $6 . 7 2 \%$ ,respectively.Coal is the most sensitive characteristic for the ADP category,and electricity is the second-most significant sensitive parameter.

4) Life Cycle Assessment Sensitivity Analysis of Biomass to MeOH

With a total sensitivity of $5 . 3 \%$ ,the sensitivity analysis of the BOTM approach in Fig.23 shows that the most sensitive parameters are the amount of electricity and steam used during the synthesis of methanol and syngas.The electricity required in the production of methanol is also the most significant sensitivity,with sensitivities of $6 . 8 8 \%$ $9 . 7 0 \%$ ,and $6 . 5 2 \%$ in the AP,HTP,and GWP impact categories,respectively.HTP also has the highest sensitivity.

In the sensitivity analysis of the CCTM route shown in Fig.24, the primary sensitive factors,apart from direct exhaust $\mathrm { C O _ { 2 } }$ input,are electricity and steam consumption.Other influential factors include representative AP,HTP vs.GWP,and combined environmental impacts. Notably, the $\mathrm { C O } _ { 2 }$ collection process demonstrates the highest sensitivity to electricity,surpassing ${ 3 \% }$ for all consequences,while total electricity usage exhibits a sensitivity of approximately $5 \%$ .This discrepancy is largely due to the substantial coal-generated electricity required for $\mathrm { C O } _ { 2 }$ capture and the significant wind energy used in hydrogen production. Moreover, steam sensitivity levels stay below $5 \%$ .This emphasizes that electricity continues to be the most important element in new methanol production pathways, similar to conventional technology routes. Nonetheless,considering its critical role in determining the environmental effects of new methanol production routes,steam sensitivity should not be undervalued.

According to the research above,the factor most sensitive to the magnitude of environmental impacts is electricity,a crucial parameter in the four main pathways for producing methanol.Furthermore, it is impossible to ignore the sensitivities of steam and electricity in the novel $\mathrm { C O _ { 2 } }$ hydrogenation process.
3.3.Electric power optimization analysis

Electricity has the greatest potential to lessen environmental consequences because it is the technology route that is most environmentally sensitive.Therefore,in this study,four forms of clean power—namely, wind power, hydropower, nuclear power,and photovoltaic power—along with conventional coal power are selected along with hybrid power in the base case scenario in order to optimize power,based on the evolution and development of China's power mix.In order to make recommendations for cleaner production in the methanol industry,a new LCA analysis is carried out to estimate the environmental effect reduction potential of the electric power optimization.

Based on China's electricity structure and development trend,this study chose the blended electricity results of the base case scenario and the accounting results of solar,wind,hydropower,nuclear,and coal power in five methanol production lines.According to the Gabi database, $7 4 . 2 3 \%$ of blended electricity is produced by burning coal, $1 6 . 9 \%$ by hydropower, $2 . 5 9 \%$ by wind, $2 . 0 5 \%$ by heavy oil, $1 . 6 6 \%$ by natural gas, $1 . 2 4 \%$ by gas,and less than $1 \%$ by other fuels.
3.3.1.Comparison of comprehensive impact emission reduction potential based on electric power optimization

Fig.25 ilustrates the outcomes of an analysis of the electricity optimization and reduction potential based on the change in the type of input electricity during the life cycle for the mitigation potential of the total environmental impacts of the five methanol production routes. Only $2 . 4 \%$ $3 . 6 \%$ $2 . 4 \%$ $2 . 3 \%$ and $3 . 2 \%$ less environmental impact is experienced overallif hybrid power completely replaces coal power. The possibility for mitigation is clear if allof the electricity is generated from specified clean and renewable energy sources,such as nuclear power. For instance,using $1 0 0 \%$ wind power would lower the combined environmental consequences for the five routes by,respectively, $7 9 . 6 \%$ $6 4 . 4 \%$ ， $8 1 . 4 \%$ ， $8 1 . 0 \%$ ，and $5 4 . 9 \%$ ，Although hydropower has the greatest potential for environmental impact reduction of the four typical routes for the production of methanol, the combined environmental impact magnitude values are very close,all around 3.0oE-09,allowing for results that are comparable to hydropower in terms of combined environmental impacts if $1 0 0 \%$ nuclear or wind power can be applied. Among the four typical routes for producing methanol, hydropower has the best potential for reduction in the scenarios when clean electricity is used. If $1 0 0 \%$ nuclear or wind power can be deployed in the typical pathways,the combined environmental effect magnitude values are extremely close to each other,all hovering around 3.ooE-O9,making it conceivable to achieve outcomes comparable to hydropower in terms of the combined environmental impacts.However,in the case where all electricity is generated by PV,the reduction potential of the CGTM, COTM,NGTM,and BOTM routes is,respectively, $7 2 . 4 \%$ $5 9 . 6 \%$ $7 3 . 7 \%$ and $7 2 . 6 \%$ ,which is slightly higher than the other cleaner energy based electricity but also much lower than the impact value of coal power.

Many gasses,like as CO2, SO2,and silicon tetrachloride,are used in the production of PV panels,which would negatively damage human health and the ecology,thereby havinga bigger total environmental impact. This is the primary reason why PV power generation has a greater environmental load.

Fig.25 further indicates that the CGTM approach holds significant potential for mitigating environmental impacts.When utilizing $1 0 0 \%$ of a clean energy source—such as wind,hydropower,or nuclear energy—the cumulative environmental impact values for both the CGTM and COGM pathways tend to converge.Additionally，in scenarios involving coal-fired electricity,the COGM,NGTM,and BOTM routes exhibit competitiveness with the CGTM pathway employing $1 0 0 \%$ clean energy power.These findings suggest that the CGTM route can vie with other conventional pathways by decommissioning power sources and circumventing existing high-pollution and energy-intensive processes. However,the outlook for the novel $\mathrm { C O } _ { 2 }$ hydrogenation route is less promising;even after electricity optimization, its overall environmental impacts surpass those of the COTM,NGTM,and BOTM routes.This underscores electricity as the paramount influencing factor within this new route, far surpassing the power dependency observed in conventional methanol production pathways.Returning to the sensitivity analysis,this research also ascertain that electricity not only possesses greater potential to influence the environmental impact of the CCTM route,but another critical parameter, steam,exhibits exceedingly high sensitivity as well.

Based on Fig.26,the integrated environmental impact reductior potential of the CCTM route exhibits substantial enhancement following the co-optimization of electricity and steam. Specifically, when applying hydropower ata $1 0 0 \%$ utilization rate, the emission reduction potential reaches an impressive $8 5 . 2 \%$ .This value stands as the highest relative reduction among all the routes and also demonstrates the largest absolute emission reduction. These findings underscore the growing significance of co-optimizing steam and electricity to facilitate cleaner production within emerging pathways.Concurrently,it's critical to recognize that the cleaner production from the new route is not up to par.The examination of process percentages indicates that,in the CCTM framework,the stage of hydrogen generation is mostly responsible for reducing environmental impact, particularly when it comes to the use of clean electricity.This highlights the significant energy requirement of hydrogen production,which is a major impediment to the route's potential for cleaner manufacturing.

3.3.2.Comparison of end-point impact emission reduction potential based on electric power optimization

Fig.27 shows how potential reductions through electricity optimization may be used to quantify the environmental effects of the two endpoint groups.The energy source wind power has a great deal of potential to affect both human health and ecosystems.Reductions of $8 5 \%$ $7 3 \%$ $9 2 \%$ ,and $9 0 \%$ are anticipated for the CGTM, COGM,NGTM, and BOTM routes,among the formerly conventional technical routes.In accordance with this,the latter group of conventional technical routes may experience reductions of $9 2 \%$ $7 4 \%$ $9 5 \%$ ,and $9 3 \%$ .However, there is a lot of mitigation potential when hydropower,nuclear power,and photovoltaic power are used instead of other power sources.Therefore, optimizing electric power stands out as one of the best approaches to successfully reduce various environmental effects.

For the more recent routes,the results of electricity optimization alone are still not clean enough,as Fig. 28 shows.After employing hydropower,the endpoint consequences on human and ecological health have reduction potentials of $6 0 . 1 \%$ and $6 1 . 5 \%$ ,respectively,which are less than those of all other conventional methods.This demonstrates that the aim of appropriately reducing each impact cannot be fully achieved by power optimization.However, the reduction potential of the innovative routes for all types of impacts after electric power optimization only is comparable to that of COTM but higher than the reduction values of NGTM and BOTM in terms of absolute values of reduction. To test the innovative route's ability to reduce each type of endpoint impact,much as with the treatment of integrated environmental impacts,steam and electricity co-optimization is required.

As seen in Fig. 28 in the CCTM, power optimization by itself still does not produce results that are clearly visible.The end-point effects of hydropower on the environment and human health are less severe than those of all other conventional techniques,at $6 0 . 1 \%$ and $6 1 . 5 \%$ respectively. This demonstrates that the goal of adequately lowering different consequences cannot be entirely attained through electric power optimization.The environmental mitigation potential of the CCTM route is equal to that of COTM after electric power optimization alone, but higher than that of NGTM and BOTM.Therefore,cooperative steam and electric electric power optimization is necessary.

- The analysis focuses on the sensitivity of five environmental impact indicators: Abiotic Depletion Potential (ADP), Acidification Potential (AP), Human Toxicity Potential (HTP), and Global Warming Potential (GWP), all measured in percentage change relative to a baseline.
